messages.text:
Hello everyone!

I’m Nathan, I’m a PhD student studying crowdsourcing/hybrid intelligence/philosophy of statistics at the Institute for Data Science & Artificial Intelligence at the University of Manchester. I’m a fairly proficient R user but have been slowly falling in love with Julia during lockdown!

I’m looking to move more of my research workflow over to Julia and eventually some of my teaching work too.
I’m particularly interested in using Julia as a GIS and learning how to develop packages for applications that don’t currently exist in Julia (such as a package for structural equation modelling, equivalent to what lavaan offers in R, and a package for multiverse/specification curve analyses).

elements.text:
Hello everyone!

I’m Nathan, I’m a PhD student studying crowdsourcing/hybrid intelligence/philosophy of statistics at the Institute for Data Science & Artificial Intelligence at the University of Manchester. I’m a fairly proficient R user but have been slowly falling in love with Julia during lockdown!

I’m looking to move more of my research workflow over to Julia and eventually some of my teaching work too.
I’m particularly interested in using Julia as a GIS and learning how to develop packages for applications that don’t currently exist in Julia (such as a package for structural equation modelling, equivalent to what lavaan offers in R, and a package for multiverse/specification curve analyses).

messages.text:
Hello everyone,
I'm Dodd (he/him), a postdoc working on a mix of topics in nonlinear optics, integrated photonics and Raman spectroscopy in the EECS dept. at MIT. I've been coming up to speed on Julia for the past several months and developing code for PDE-constrained optimization ("inverse design") of waveguides for short laser pulses. Migrating from using python to control compiled PDE solver libraries has been surprisingly approachable thanks to all of the great ongoing work in the Julia community and is already proving useful for my research. I am excited to join and hopefully contribute to the ecosystem.
I am currently focused on automatic differentiation applied to eigenmode solutions of parameterized PDEs (just the Helmholtz equation for now), Other relevant buzzwords include "adjoint method" and "matrix-free"/"implicit" operators. Please feel free to reach out if you have overlapping interests and would like to chat. I look forward to learning from/with you all.

elements.text:

I'm Dodd (he/him), a postdoc working on a mix of topics in nonlinear optics, integrated photonics and Raman spectroscopy in the EECS dept. at MIT. I've been coming up to speed on Julia for the past several months and developing code for PDE-constrained optimization ("inverse design") of waveguides for short laser pulses. Migrating from using python to control compiled PDE solver libraries has been surprisingly approachable thanks to all of the great ongoing work in the Julia community and is already proving useful for my research. I am excited to join and hopefully contribute to the ecosystem.
I am currently focused on automatic differentiation applied to eigenmode solutions of parameterized PDEs (just the Helmholtz equation for now), Other relevant buzzwords include "adjoint method" and "matrix-free"/"implicit" operators. Please feel free to reach out if you have overlapping interests and would like to chat. I look forward to learning from/with you all.

messages.text:
Hello,
I am an engineer doing sensor characterization and calibrations for a manufacturing company in Canada.
I started using Julia in 2017 to avoid writing complex wrappers in python. Had some fights with management over the years over it's use, and it looks like 2021 is the year where it's usage is finally accepted by management.

messages.text:
Hi everyone :wave:
I’m a 2nd year PhD student and I decided that the moment has come for me to learn Julia :smile:
What are the best resources you would suggest to get into the field (not too basic however, I’ve been programming –scientific programming, and mostly Python– for years now)?
I found the course _Introduction to Computational Thinking_ by MIT which uses Julia and looks great, do you suggest it? <https://computationalthinking.mit.edu/Spring21/>
Have any other valuable resource?

Thanks, and have a great week! :party_parrot:

messages.text: Hey, I'm a data scientist and I'm taking Julia for a ride, especially trying out Turing.jl and how it compares with PyMC3 and Stan! So far I really love the documentation and examples, though I find it always a little difficult to get into the syntax of a new language (after 10+ years of Python, 1 year of R). It does seem to have a relatively low learning curve, which is great :wink:

messages.text: Hi All! joining to see how I can incorporate Julia into commercial SaaS product development. I did a DS certificate to get my foot into the industry and having worked a lot with compiled languages such as Swift, Go, C# to name a few left me a bit unsatisfied when using Python as the primary language for DS exploration and modeling. I've just started learning Julia but I hope I can contribute to it in the near future! to start I'll just be trying out the ML basics from python to Julia, if anyone can share good resources that would be awesome!

messages.text:
Hello guys. I am an associate professor of Smart Cities and Urban Planning at Universidade Nove de Julho located in São Paulo Brazil. I currently advise PhD candidates and also teach graduates and undergraduates in Stats, Bayesian Stats, Machine Learning, Deep Learning. My main focus (and passion) is probabilistic languages and Bayesian Statistics. I currently contribute to Stan and I am also looking to help in turing.

I've been dabbling with Julia for 2 years now. From 2021 onwards I realized that Julia is the future of scientific computing and everything new I am doing it in Julia with research, classes, students and candidates.

Such a welcoming community. I would like to express my deepest gratitude and I am here to contribute and help as much as I can.

Hello! My name is Pedro Sánchez and I'm from a little city in the southeast of Spain called Caravaca de la Cruz.
I did a BSc in Biotechnology from 2015 to 2019 and then I decided to learn more about data analysis so I entered in the MSc in Biostatistics I'm currently finishing.
Although I feel more at home with R, I've decided to learn Julia more deeply. Hope to see lot of good knowledge and kind people in this slack :smiley:

messages.text: Hi! I'm Arif. I am a postdoc at ICTS-TIFR, India where I work on gravitational wave astrophysics and waveform modeling using numerical relativity. I am a member of the LIGO-VIRGO collaboration and also a member of the Simulating eXtreme Spacetime (SXS) collaboration. I am starting to learn more about Julia by using it as the primary language for a course on compact objects <https://github.com/md-arif-shaikh/Physics-Of-Compact-Objects>. Looking forward to enhance my Julia knowledge further.

messages.text:
Hey there!! I am a 3rd year college undergraduate interested in Data Science, ML, DL etc. particularly Reinforcement learning.

I am someone who is happy to learn something new everyday and so far my learning experience in this background has been incredible Looking forward to learn more on my interests and develop some expertise. I am relatively new to Julia but have some familiarity in other frameworks but the more I seem to venture into the language the more I seem to fall in love with it.

I am looking for contributing to open source and I really feel that this might be a great place to start. If anyone could point to where I could start, that would be really helpful.
